results.title: Eric Worrell: they don't shoot bathtubs
results.brief_description: Part of the “See it my way” series, in this program Eric Worrell outlines his views on conservation of the environment, based on the premise that, if the individual starts to rebuild the ecological balance of their own garden, they will encourage others such as business organisations, councils and governments to follow suit on a wider scale. He gives several examples of companies that have established sanctuary areas for the animal population side by side with areas used for economic purposes. He also cites other examples where the environment has been totally destroyed in the pursuit of economic expansion.

results.title: Equus
results.creator_credit: Sidney Lumet, Lester Persky, Elliott Kastner, Denis Holt and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Peter Firth plays Alan Strang, a young man working as a stableboy at an upper-class riding school who one night brutally blinds the horses. Richard Burton is psychiatrist Dr. Martin Dysart who is investigating the reasons for the young man’s apparent senseless crime. Based on Peter Shaffer’s acclaimed play, “Equus” is a film that explores and manages to traverse a rich field of themes and concerns: psychoanalysis and mythology; sexuality and repression; class and family; sex and power. The relationship between analyst and patient becomes increasingly complex as the mysteries of the boy’s repressions become unravelled. The men’s exchanges begin to be complicated by the echoes of homoeroticism and the psychological overtones of the Oedipal Complex. Though dominated by the performances of Burton and Firth, “Equus” features an excellent supporting cast including Joan Plowright, Eileen Atkins and Jenny Agutter. Initially dividing critics, “Equus” has become a cult favourite through the years and is acknowledged as one of Lumet’s darker and innovative works.

results.title: Enough Rope: Can I Write the Ending?
results.creator_credit: Kerry Brewster, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Zapruder's Other Films
results.brief_description: What would you do if you thought you were about to die? This is an inspiring and moving story of three strong women, Annie Robinson, Nadeen Kovacic and Jasmyne Russell, each confronting life’s hardest journey, and how they’ve chosen to face their cancer and its ramifications. Presented by Andrew Denton, first broadcast on ABC Television on September 10, 2007.

results.title: Equality. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Art Ciocco, Paul Buck, Ken Stein, New Jersey Public Television and Best Films
results.brief_description: Explores the diversity of people and the breadth of the problems as one searches for “equality”. Concentrates on two basic areas, sex and race. Contains some b&w sequences.

results.title: Epsilon
results.creator_credit: Rolf De Heer, Domenico Procacci, Fandango and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: This unusual early feature from Rolf de Heer is an intergalactic love-story between a woman from the outer space, who is sent from the planet Epsilon to pass judgment on the shameful way in which humans have mishandled their planet, and an earthbound man. Stunning land/nightscapes (the outback, great cities, and vista’s full of stars) are major characters as the two map the spaces, times and places of the heart. Cast includes Ulli Birve and Syd Brisbane.

results.title: Epiphytes
results.credit_line:
2022

Tully Arnot, b. 1984, Gadigal land

Lives and works, Hong Kong

Free-roam virtual reality environment, spatial sound, scent, carpet, reading room

Created in collaboration with Dr Josh Harle of Tactical Space Lab
results.material_description: Oculus Quest 2 virtual reality headset, APK files, reading material, furniture and mixed media
results.brief_description: Epiphytes is a VR work by Australian artist Tully Arnot promoting a plant-based perspective. Reflecting Arnot’s interest in how emergent technologies help form human understanding of the world, the visually diffuse nature of the work is deliberate. In Epiphytes, the primacy of sight is de-escalated, and sound and scent become key - used by Arnot to manipulate our bodily responses within the virtual space. “Epiphytes” encourages audiences to adjust the way we understand our own senses of perception by drawing our attention to alternative forms of plant communication and consciousness.

constellations_primary.name: Plants and people
constellations_primary.description: Plants can be characters in stories, and we often project human qualities onto them, but how do they see the world?

results.description:
An epiphyte is an organism that lives on the surface of a plant, feeding on the air, water and natural refuse of its environment, in harmony with its surrounding ecosystem. Tully Arnot’s virtual reality work Epiphytes honours alternative forms of plant communication and consciousness, inviting us to question our own perception. The primacy of sight is minimised in favour of sound and scent, which Arnot uses to influence our bodily responses within the virtual space. Epiphytes reflects Arnot’s interest in how emergent technologies help form human understandings of the world.

Situated within an abstracted representation of Arnot’s childhood backyard, the environment features a diffuse, shifting, magenta palette - suggestive of a phytomorphic (plant-based) interpretation of light and space. The work includes interviews with evolutionary ecologist Monica Gagliano, acoustic archaeologist Umashankar Manthravadi and echolocation teacher/blind researcher and activist Thomas Tajo.

Tully Arnot is one of Australia’s leading visual artists. Arnot’s practice explores the effect that contemporary technology has on human relationships, looking at the isolating nature of our increasingly connected, but ultimately disconnected world. Themes of automation and simulation feature strongly in Arnot’s work, while relationships between human and vegetal worlds are explored as allegory for social or political structures.

Arnot completed a Bachelor of Design, Honours (2009), and Master of Fine Arts (Research) (2014) at UNSWA+D. His international residencies include an exchange at Universitat der Kunste Berlin in 2013 with Gregor Schneider, as well as masterclasses at Donghua University Shanghai and Politechnico di Milano through Richard Goodwin’s Porosity Studio. In 2020-2021 Arnot was a City of Sydney Creative Fellowship artist, and his work has been shown widely both locally and internationally.

results.title: Epilepsy: first aid for seizures
results.creator_credit: Ernie Steck, Paul Eide and University of Minnesota
results.brief_description: Dispels the myths that surround epilepsy and informs on the facts. Provides information on how to recognise the various forms of epilepsy - petit mal, grand mal, partial seizure and post-ictal state. The treatment required for these various stages of epilepsy is also noted. Narrated by Mark frost. Suitable for middle and upper secondary and tertiary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ernie Steck, Paul Eide and University of Minnesota

results.title: Entities
results.creator_credit: OOM Creative, MORE Studio, Greg More (OOM Creative), Pete Brundle (MORE Studio) and James Sandri (MORE Studio)
results.brief_description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

constellations_primary.name: Future visions
constellations_primary.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

results.creator_credit_for_label: OOM Creative, MORE Studio, Greg More (OOM Creative), Pete Brundle (MORE Studio) and James Sandri (MORE Studio)
results.description:
We leave a trace whenever we interact with a digital system: a thread of data that lingers like a ghost within a machine.

Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections. Each time an object is collected, the visualisation updates in real-time to create a dynamic living map of our visitors’ journey: the more people in the space, the more active it becomes. Created by code and contemporary web technologies, Entities encourages visitors to discover new objects and artworks by seeing what others are collecting in the gallery over time.
description_for_label:

Created by code and contemporary web technologies, Entities encourages visitors to discover new objects and artworks by seeing what others are collecting in the gallery over time.

results.title: Entertaining with Isabel Jones
results.brief_description: Isabelle Jones, cookery broadcaster and journalist, shows you step-by-step how simple cooking and entertaining really is. This 60-minute video features four different menus for six people. Over 25 tried and tested, delicious recipes in the accompanying cover booklet. Table setting ideas, lots of cooking tips, quick and easy methods. Rated: G

results.title: Entertaining angels
results.creator_credit: Michael Rhodes, Elwood Kieser and Paulist Pictures
results.brief_description: ‘Entertaining Angels’ is based on the true life of Dorothy Day, a radical journalist who lived in New York writing about the plight of America’s homeless. She has an early love affair with a co-worker which results in a traumatic abortion that sees her move to the coast to be alone. While staying at the beach Dorothy (Moira Kelly) comes across and old friend and the two fall in love. It is at this time that Dorothy begins to question her faith after some close contact with one of the nuns who runs a shelter for the disadvantaged. Dorothy falls pregnant to Foster and although happy for a while, she refuses to give up her religion and he refuses to marry, once again Dorothy is alone but ready to move back to the city. Dorothy and her daughter are baptized Catholics and Dorothy resumes her career as a journalist, only this time starting her own paper, “The Catholic Worker” after meeting Peter, a French social activist. Dorothy combines her journalism and charity at home, offering the homeless a soup kitchen, shelter and office where she can work on the paper. This is an inspiring film that was made on a relatively small budget by Paulist Pictures who also brought us ‘Romero’.
